data.name: German Unicode Characters to ASCII Equivalents
data.description:
# The Problem You work for a German company that just bought some legacy components from the US. Unfortunately, these legacy components can only accept ASCII characters. (Here is a [list of ASCII printable characters](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ASCII#ASCII_printable_characters).) This means that you will need to convert all non-ASCII German Unicode characters into their standard ASCII equivalent. # Your Job Write a class (**GermanToAscii**) that will help in transcoding German-specific Unicode characters into their ASCII equivalent. The characters should be transcoded as follows:
Unicode Character Unicode Value ASCII Equivalent
ä U+00E4 ae
ö U+00F6 oe
ü U+00FC ue
Ä U+00C4 Ae
Ö U+00D6 Oe
Ü U+00DC Ue
ß U+00DF ss
# Requirements Create a class **GermanToAscii** that will assist in translating according to the above table. ## initialize(unknown) Although you are only tasked with translating umlauted characters, you cannot assume that the string will have no other non-ASCII characters. **initialize** should thus accept an **unknown** parameter that specifies how to respond to unknown non-ASCII characters (i.e., non-umlaut, non-ß): * **:ignore** Render an empty string in place of each non-ASCII character. (E.g., 'crée' => 'cre'.) * **:leave** Leave non-ASCII characters as-is. (This will cause **String#encode** to raise an **Encoding::UndefinedConversionError**.) * **<String>** Replace unknown characters with the given string. (E.g., if it is '?', then 'crée' => 'cr?e'.) **unknown** should default to a question mark ('?'). ## transcode_char_lambda(char) Returns a lambda that accepts a parameter **char** which: * converts the char, according to the rules above, if it is an umlaut-character or a ß. * otherwise, if **unknown** was set to **:leave**, returns the character; and if **unknown** was set to a replacement string, returns the replacement string. You can assume that this lambda will only be called with length-1 strings consisting of a single non-ASCII character. ## render(str) Transcode **str** as described above from UTF-8 to ASCII. You can assume that **str** will be a String. (Note that it is not enough simply to change over the characters: the return value must respond to `#encoding` with `#`.) # Tips As far as I know, you cannot type Unicode characters directly into your code or test cases in CodeWars. Instead, use the unicode code values listed above (e.g. "\u00e4" for 'ä'). You will need to use **String#encode** (http://ruby-doc.org/core-2.0.0/String.html#method-i-encode). You may also find it helpful to look at the **Encoding** class: http://ruby-doc.org/core-2.0.0/Encoding.html.
